docs.snippet: " It took a horrible war to make us improve Pan-American relationships," said Joseph T. Mackey, president of the Mergenthaler Linotype Company, who gave a luncheon yesterday in the Hotel Roosevelt for nine visiting journalists and publishers from...
docs.lead_paragraph: " It took a horrible war to make us improve Pan-American relationships," said Joseph T. Mackey, president of the Mergenthaler Linotype Company, who gave a luncheon yesterday in the Hotel Roosevelt for nine visiting journalists and publishers from Peru and Uruguay.
docs.abstract: Gives luncheon for South Amer journalists on US tour; s on inter-Amer relations

docs.snippet: NOT long ago the United States air mails in New York received a small carton. It was about as large as a spool of thread, and weighed less than an ounce. The wartime need for more air mail space might have long delayed a larger package, but not this...
docs.lead_paragraph: NOT long ago the United States air mails in New York received a small carton. It was about as large as a spool of thread, and weighed less than an ounce. The wartime need for more air mail space might have long delayed a larger package, but not this one, which was soon tossed into a convenient mail bag and forgotten.
docs.abstract: Micro-filmed scripts shipped from US to Latin Amer discussed

docs.snippet: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 1 -- Juan Jose de Amezaga, who was elected President of Uruguay last Nov. 29, took oath of office before the General Legislative Assembly this afternoon and received from the hands of outgoing President General Alfredo...
docs.lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 1 -- Juan Jose de Amezaga, who was elected President of Uruguay last Nov. 29, took oath of office before the General Legislative Assembly this afternoon and received from the hands of outgoing President General Alfredo Baldomir the badge of Presidential office consisting of a sash of Uruguay's national colors.

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, March l7 -- Eric A. Johnston, President of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, returned tonight from a 20,000-mile airplane trip to seven Latin-American countries and will report to President Roosevelt that they do not want "A...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March l7 -- Eric A. Johnston, President of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, returned tonight from a 20,000-mile airplane trip to seven Latin-American countries and will report to President Roosevelt that they do not want "A South American WPA," financed by the United States Government but would welcome American capital and management into joint, cooperative private corporations.
docs.abstract: E A Johnston urges US businessmen to study pol economics

headline.main: JOHNSTON REPORTS LATINS 'RECEPTIVE'; Chamber President, After Tour, Says South Americans Prefer 'Free Enterprise' SHUN 'WPA EXTENSION' Development of Countries by Private Capital Is Favored, He Will Tell Roosevelt
